Description

Used idiomatic javascript to avoid complex array functions. The rest operator is used to collect all the remaining argument of the function. So instead of taking the whole list and then popping the first element (this is expensive), we simply retain the first argument as a variable first and the rest of the arguments are stored as array in rest variable. Then we just change the order of arguments.
I think this code is easy to grok and is much faster and more ES6.
const flip = fn => (first, ...rest) => fn(...rest, first);
Note -
Intentionally used the word rest instead of args because I felt for this case rest better helps people understand that , rest holds all the args after first arg. If I have used args then it partly implies that first is not an arg which is not true

I've added a handy utility snippet that checks whether a provided value is negative zero or not.
Before you make a noise, let me explain a bit how JavaScript handles numbers and why is this function useful to some people.
JavaScript 0 and -0 examples
0 === -0 //  true
0 / 3 // equals to 0
0 / -3 // equals to  -0

Infinity === -Infinity // false
Yes. I know that negative zero doesn't exist in real Math but this is just how JavaScript engine threats it. Whenever JavaScript engine works with dividing negatives, it treats them as positives and adds - afterward.
Usage
Not much as you've guessed it but this function can be used when writing complex animations, a -0 on just finished animation can provide information on whether the animation was coming from the right or the left side etc.

Description
Some expectations involving asynchronous tests were not working. By default, Jest tests complete once they reach the end of their execution. If there are assertions on asynchronous code, but we don't make Jest aware of it, those tests will simply pass.
There are specific ways to make Jest wait for expectations:
For callback-based code, we can introduce the done argument on each test. This is a callback function provided by Jest. Each test will wait for this callback to be executed after the desired assertions are done. If the done callback is not invoked, the test will timeout.
For promise-based code, we can simply return the promise from the test and use run the expectations on the then. Or we can use the resolves / rejects helpers.
Finally, we can use also async / await, by making the test closure async, and using await get the values to do the expectations.
More details about this on the official docs.

hasKey snippet is really handy to check for inner keys in nested objects. Unfortunately current implementation of it fails for a particular case:
(Where one key is prefix of another and it has object value, in this case b & b.c)
let obj = {
  'a': 1,
  'b': { 'e': 4 },
  'b.c': 5
};

hasKey(obj, 'b.c');
// should return "true" but returns "false"

The above scenario can not be handled with current method signature of accepting second argument as string. Using function signature where it accepts Array of keys, we can address above scenario along with other simpler cases.
This also simplifies overall implementation of function without using any recursion or string manipulations. With Array as key list, we can use Array.prototype.every() to simplify and early return on failure.


This PR updates hasKey snippet to handle this failing cases along with existing ones and simplifies overall implementation of the function.

This changes signature of hasKey snippet to accept list of strings instead of just a string, which can be called as a breaking change.

The Issue(s)
As shared in issue#1175. The current code fails to restore nested properties and doesnot cater for scenairos like
unflattenObject({ 'a.b': 1, 'a.c': 2, d: 3 })
unflattenObject({ 'a.b': 'foo', d: 3 })
where either the same key is being refered more than once or the values are non numbers. More detials can be seen in this runkit shared in the issue as well.
An additional scenario which the code failed to handle was when the flat path reffered to particular indices in the arrays values against a key. For example.
unflattenObject({ 'a.b.0': 5, d: 3 })
should return something like {a:{b:[5]}, d: 3}. However, the code fails to compile.
Solution
I fixed the snippet to handle these scenarios along with some improvements. The updated code which passes all these tests can be seen in this runkit.
Modifications / Improvements
The previous code uses JSON.parse() to parse the manually built string into JSON and then merges it with the accumulator using Object.assign(). This happened for ever iteration of Array.prototype.reduce(). My code takes a slightly different approach of making the reference to the values as the next accumulator. This ways, I can directly mutate and nested objects without having to merge on each iteration. This arguably improves the performance fo the code.
